channel.title: Cost of an object in Java?
channel.description:
In my application, I'm creating a heck of a lot of objects and was wanted to know how much of an impact it has on memory. I'm using a List often and I'm not sure how well the GC acts. Sake of simplicity imagine a List being created every 100ms and used once.
NB: I'm not looking for optimisation advise.

item.title: Cost of an object in Java?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

write some C, C++, or Rust and then worry about problems like this. it’s not like you’re touching the hardware or having much control over allocation lifespans anyway.

Read full topic
item.source: Cost of an object in Java?

item.title: Cost of an object in Java?
item.dc:creator: @my-swagger my-swagger
item.description:
@my-swagger wrote:

This topics going off topic. I don’t need the code criticism.
I’m very well aware of Queue and I am using them!

I have got the answer to my question. I’ll be reusing what I can when appropriate and will stick to buffers.

Read full topic
item.source: Cost of an object in Java?

item.title: Cost of an object in Java?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

[quote=“my-swagger, post:6, topic:554145”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=673068.msg4500915#msg4500915 date=1450563262]

Well the alternative would be to have 1 list, then clear it every 100ms.

Then do that… Why penalise yourself with the recreation of an entirely new list…
[/quote]
That’s the question. Is it very costly to do so?[/quote]

Well, for example, ArrayList simply iterates over the internal array and sets all members to be null. The GC should pick up all these elements on its next sweep, nothing too tragic about that.

I’ve only just noticed this line:

Why are you using a List to model a Queue? There are plenty of queue implementations in the standard libraries, assuming you’re choosing readability and robustness over pure performance.

Read full topic
item.source: Cost of an object in Java?

item.title: Cost of an object in Java?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Generally speaking Java’s GC is optimised for allocation of small objects. The main issue that might arise is memory fragmentation, depending on how the virtual machine is carving up system memory provided to you on the heap.

The reality is that you probably want to re-use the same list but what you’re currently doing won’t be a deal breaker.

Read full topic

Thanks for the input.

item.title: Cost of an object in Java?
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

clear the list don’t recreate it, hell even just resetting the write head will suffice

you shouldn’t be using lists either, I did that with wakenet at first just to quickly mockup the design but they’re a lot slower. You should just use byte[buffersize] once and make your buffer size a power of two depending on how much data you’re sending and how frequently

Read full topic

item.source: Cost of an object in Java?

item.title: Cost of an object in Java?
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Eyeownyew, post:7, topic:554145”][quote author=my-swagger link=topic=673068.msg4500917#msg4500917 date=1450563506]

Well the alternative would be to have 1 list, then clear it every 100ms.

Then do that… Why penalise yourself with the recreation of an entirely new list…

That’s the question. Is it very costly to do so?
[/quote]
It’s reallocating memory that you could just be reusing instead. Regardless of whether it’s costly or not, one is clearly the better decision[/quote]
This. And also ArrayLists take up the same memory as an empty Object (8 bytes) + an int containing the size of the arraylist (4 bytes) + an array of an n-amount of Objects.
Also, [font=Verdana]every time you add something that makes the arraylist larger than its current size, it creates a new Object array that is one larger than the previous size.[/font]

[font=verdana, arial, helvetica, sans-serif]You could try making a static array of Packets whose size is set by default to a constant “MAX_QUEUED_PACKETS” and you just keep track of the last index that a packet was put into and manipulate the static Packet array the way you’d like.[/font]

Read full topic
item.source: Cost of an object in Java?

Then do that… Why penalise yourself with the recreation of an entirely new list…
[/quote]

item.title: Cost of an object in Java?
item.dc:creator: @my-swagger my-swagger
item.description:
@my-swagger wrote:

[quote=“Eyeownyew, post:2, topic:554145”]You shouldn’t be creating a list every 100ms and using it once, at that point you should definitely be reusing memory
Regardless, if you’re using memory correctly (and reusing indices instead of making a new list every 100ms), memory is not nearly as important to optimize as processing efficiency. The size of classes is unnoticeable unless you use just an absolutely absurd amount of them, which requires very bad practices in the first place[/quote]
Well the alternative would be to have 1 list, then clear it every 100ms. I’m only using a List to store incoming data then quickly process it. Coding is just easier and flexible when using a List.

As for my code, I don’t really want to show it but here’s what it consists of:

[code=java]class Channel {
List queue = new ArrayList<>();

public List getQueue() { … }
public void add(Packet p) { queue.add§; }
}[/code]

[code=java]class Network implements Runnable {
Socket socket;
Channel inChannel;
Channel outChannel;

Network() { … }

void run() {
while (true) {
read();
send();
}
}

void read() {
Packet p = new Packet();
p.queue(socket.readAll);
inChannel.add§;
}

void send() {
List queue = outChannel.getQueue();
for (byte b : queue) {
socket.write(b);
}
}

}
[/code]

[code=java]class Packet {
List data = new ArrayList<>();

void queue(byte b) { data.add(b); }

…

}[/code]

Sorry for the bad formatting wrote in message box. Just a mockup, the actual code is abit better.

Read full topic
